comments: Are there infinitely many terms not divisible by 100? - _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Sep 19 2012Yes. For example, the squares of the type (k*10^m+1)^2, where m>0 and k = 2, 70, 970, 202470000  or  m>1 and k = 10^m-3, belong to the sequence. - _Bruno Berselli_, Jan 10 2013
references: Sylvester Smith, "A Set of Conjectures on Smarandache Sequences", Bulletin of Pure and Applied Sciences, (Bombay, India), Vol. 15 E (No. 1), 1996, pp. 101-107.
links: Eric Weisstein's World of Mathematics, Smarandache Sequences
prog: (MAGMA) [n^2: n in [0..2000] | forall{d: d in Intseq(n^2) | d in [0,1,4,9]}]; // _Bruno Berselli_, Jan 10 2013
author: R. Muller
